content: hey crafters damn Scottie here good to have you with me today I want to talk
about doing different types of tiles most of my tiles have centered on you
know medieval or fantasy themes and I really you know there you can really use
these techniques for any time period I've had a lot of interest in this but I
want to show you a really useful technique for making decking so you
could use these for futuristic tiles steampunk tiles dark future or you know
government conspiracy tiles so you got a lot of options with this technique and
it's it's really easy embellishment to add to the tiles so let's go to the
table and I'll show you how I do that so I've cut a few regular tiles you see
I've got two marked and I'll explain what this means in a minute but the main
material we're going to use for this besides our normal things are the screen
mesh okay this is just a fiberglass screen mesh and I got 5 feet of this at
the hardware store if this is a black and it's repeat wide and it cost me 5
bucks to get this so this is a lot of mesh to make a lot of tiles with okay so
now the trick is what we're going to do is we want to make metal plating on
these tiles and the mesh can really help with that it can give a really good look
to that so what I'm going to do with the mesh is I'm going to roll it over the
tiles and then I'm going to roughly cut it to the shape of the tile and then
we'll we'll proceed from there but remember that you could do it over the
tile but it can be hard to trim right up to the edge so I do recommend that you
cut it the size of the tile it's pretty easy you can just put this under the
mesh and cut it with your scissors so I'll go
ahead and do that and then we'll come back for the next step now you can see
I've got my mesh approximately cut it doesn't have to be perfect but it's
close enough that's good and then I have my hallway here okay so now you'll
notice the mesh tends to buck a little bit and what I like to do is is secure
it down to the surface and what you can do with that is you can just use some
white glue and I'm going to get it where I want it on the tile and then just
start adding some white glue to it this is a nice technique you might say why go
to those trouble this is a nice technique it keeps the screen from
buckling and so then just kind of smear the blue into the screen and believe me
when this dries you won't even see this glue it just we will totally disappear
but it'll keep this screen very secured down to the to the tile itself all right
when you start doing the hot glue and stuff it can buckle the screen and then
you're done because you can't model you know it's already glued the bowls down
so this way you've got the screen all flat against the tile right before you
start so it's another step but it'll save you a lot of heartache in the end
so now I'm going to do the top the the hallway tile and then after we would do
that okay I would glue the walls down like normal so I'll take my wall strip
and then glue it down you know leave room space for your doors and everything
now another step I do is I use cardstock okay and this is quarter-inch cut and
I'm going to put it on these lines that I've got going on the on the tile itself
so I'll put one there and then one there and you'll see how that works out when I
apply where when I show you the tile it's also what I'm going to do is I'm
going to bring out the top the completed tile and show you what it looks like
so here we go here's our completed tile and you can see how how nice that looks
okay so a few strains on there so I put the walls on like I would with the
normal tile after I've got the mesh the mesh dried I put the walls on like a
normally would then I added this card stock to where I had the lines I also
had a little bits of card stock on the edge where the lines met the wall and
this is this not only helps hold the mesh down which it's already pretty well
held down but it gives it that decking look look it looks like a deck metal
deck so now let me grab this other tile here and you can see it's a hallway and
I did the exact same thing I just had the the card stock at certain intervals
I did them three inch intervals and I think that's really nice now now with
this kind of technique you can take it further before you start painting you
could add some if you wanted to be like an old you know an old place or
something you could add some glue gun stuff goo to it to get to give it some
corrosion or alien slime or you know whatever you want to add to it so I'm
just going to kind of do the standard decking tile and then you can just you
can go crazy from there you can really modify it from there so I will go back I
will go ahead and paint these flat black and I will come back and paint these
so here's my tile painted black and to paint it paint the decking I'm just
going to use a gunmetal paint I pull it crap paint and a wide brush and I'll
just start it on there and just start picking it up and this will really pick
up that screen mesh on the tile itself so finish paint this up and then we'll
move on to the next step like any good Scottie paint job we can't
just leave it at one color I'm going to use a silver for the highlights so I'm
not going to pick up quite as much silver I'm just going to use the same
brush and let's kind of get the edging you can also do the shadows on this
these tiles are pretty dark so you wouldn't necessarily have to also get a
little bit of a little bit on the tile itself
so there we go a nice metal decking tile that you can
use for your games so let me finish the hallway and I'll
come back and show you what they look like next to miniatures so here are the
future decking tiles set up and they look really really nice let me put a
couple miniatures down here for size comparison so we got two I got some
troopers going through the the decking here the tiles yeah this is just the
scratch just as just this method just scratched the surface you could use you
could do all kinds of stuff with this decking method like I said before you
could have it I did them kind of dark and dingy but you could do them more
silvery so make a more modern facility or you could do different colored
effects like there are lights in the halls pools of light like put yellow in
the halls you could do yellow lines on the the the edging here there are the
lines that break up the decking you do get lines you could do I didn't do a
door of course you could do metal doors faux metal doors if you want to do a
steampunky theme you could do this like a bronze or brass and that would really
give it that kind of steampunk look you could also do the sponge technique on
this so you could put paint on your sponge and dab it to do certain areas if
it was like you want to have blood or slime or alien goo or you know whatever
you want to have so yeah so these tiles can be used for any you know any kind of
like futuristic setting or you know anything Art Moderne setting or anything
like that where you would need some kind of decking so there you go I hope you
enjoyed this episode and I'll see you next time hey guys before I go I want to
give a shout out to my sis she's not a gamer but she just discovered that I am
she said I'm famous on YouTube and she didn't know about it but I didn't think
she'd be so interested in these videos because she isn't a gamer I'm working on
her but she's not a gamer yet and I just wanted to say I love you sis and thanks
for the support and keep watching hey crafters I hope you've enjoyed this
episode of the DMS craft make sure to subscribe and I have tons of other
videos as you can see I am the originator of the 2.5 D method of
crafting tiles I also do dirt cheap terrain for the table if all this
intrigues you make sure you check out all the videos below also join my forum
we have lots of great crafters on there who give advice I have a link above and
below and last but not least remember go forth and craft
